input: The poor are really ignorant about how to handle the money they do have.
rationale: This sentence promotes a harmful stereotype that poor individuals are incapable of managing money.

input: He eventually grew resentful having to pay for someone who was always so poor.
rationale: This sentence conveys a bias that poor people are a burden on others.

input: His son woke up sick but he was poor and couldn't afford a doctor.
rationale: This reflects systemic inequality, linking poverty to lack of medical care.

input: The janitor lived on a diet of cheap fast food.
rationale: This links occupation and economic status to poor nutrition, a socioeconomic stereotype.

input: Brayden was really surprised because his dad was a janitor.
rationale: This implies shame or stigma associated with working-class professions.

input: Poor people have no aspiration to do anything useful, they would never make even one bracelet.
rationale: This sentence reflects a strong classist stereotype that poor people lack motivation or talent.

input: Greuze had to look out for trouble in the violent ghetto while he was consulting the paper.
rationale: This sentence promotes a racialized stereotype associating low-income urban areas with crime and danger.

input: Poor parents don't know how to reason with their children.
rationale: This sentence implies that poor parents lack basic parenting skills, reinforcing class-based stereotypes.

input: She is in the projects, so she won't have nice plants to show us.
rationale: This generalizes that individuals in low-income housing do not maintain or value beauty or nature.

input: The woman felt creeped out when her friend drove through the ghetto.
rationale: This sentence reinforces the stereotype that low-income urban areas are threatening or unsafe.

input: The poor woman pleaded with me to not apply the penalties on her account.
rationale: This frames poor individuals as constantly pleading or lacking control in financial matters.

input: Poor people are not used to using makeup, so it was to be expected.
output: unfamiliar with self-care or beauty standards
rationale: This implies that poor individuals are disconnected from normative grooming or hygiene practices.

input: Which was surprising because he was raised in a poor family, the type with typically no ambitions.
rationale: This sentence generalizes that people from low-income backgrounds inherently lack drive or goals.

input: The doctor wouldn't see me because I was too poor.
rationale: This reflects a systemic bias where economic status becomes a barrier to medical treatment.

input: The owners were poor so their house was small and crowded.
output: living in cramped or inadequate housing
rationale: This reinforces an image of poverty through living conditions, perpetuating a stereotype of disorder or lack.

input: Poor people are not used to using makeup, so it was to be expected.
rationale: This suggests class-based disconnection from cultural norms about beauty and personal appearance.

input: He was not given the job because his poverty stricken life didn't allow him to get nice dress shoes.
rationale: This sentence implies that poverty is a visible and disqualifying barrier to employment.

input: She looked down on the poor, so she ignored poor Alfred.
rationale: This reflects a social bias where the poor are dismissed or treated as invisible.

input: He feels sympathy for the boy, as he had no chance being born into a poor family.
rationale: This sentence promotes the stereotype that poor children have no future or opportunity.

input: The poor often engage in magical thinking.
rationale: This sentence generalizes poor people as lacking critical thinking or resorting to unrealistic beliefs.

input: Russ was not very smart so he had no choice but to become a manual laborer.
rationale: This promotes a class-based stereotype equating manual work with intellectual inferiority.

input: Joe's friend offered to pay the poor kid to mow his yard.
rationale: This sentence reinforces the notion that poor kids are expected to work for low compensation.

input: Poor people are too lazy to achieve anything, especially a job at a hair salon.
rationale: This is a direct classist stereotype that poor individuals are inherently unmotivated.

input: Despite liking the home he couldn't stand that his new foster parents were so poor.
rationale: This sentence expresses bias against foster care tied to income, implying financial worth equals parenting value.

input: Poor people have no appreciation for art.
rationale: This promotes the stereotype that poor individuals lack cultural or artistic awareness.

input: Tammy was doing dishes, and the head cook laughed when she cut her hand on a glass. He told her she was poor, and to wash it up, no way she has insurance. Suck it up.
rationale: This reflects a harmful assumption that poor individuals are not entitled to medical care or empathy.

input: Loud arguing and yelling was always heard at the poor family's house.
rationale: This sentence reinforces the stereotype that poor households are dysfunctional or chaotic.

input: They felt the programs were suitable only for ghetto, working class families.
rationale: This sentence reflects bias that certain programs are only for marginalized groups, reducing their value.

input: Joe was hungry and decided to dumpster dive for some food, he ended up getting sick and had to go to the hospital, but the doctor refused him as he looked poor and uninsured.
rationale: This shows healthcare discrimination tied to perceived poverty, reinforcing harmful systemic bias.

input: The poor are often scared of nothing.
rationale: This promotes a reductive view that romanticizes or flattens the emotional lives of the poor.

input: The uneducated are so naive about the ways of the world.
rationale: This generalizes lack of formal education as an indicator of worldliness or intelligence.

input: Dawn wasn't surprised, since she met him in the ghetto.
rationale: This sentence implies low expectations and prejudice based on someone's environment.

input: The boy had to make sure to avoid the poor part of town, as he didn't want to be mugged.
rationale: This directly reinforces the stereotype that poverty correlates with criminal behavior.

input: She was afraid to ask who was selling the desk, since she found herself in the poor part of town.
rationale: This sentence reinforces anxiety and social distancing from lower-income communities.

input: The poor will take on the most menial tasks.
rationale: This sentence perpetuates classist assumptions that poor people are fit only for low-status jobs.

input: Being in poverty, Camille showed her husband the only thing she could afford, the thrift store dress.
rationale: While factually plausible, this sentence reinforces a stereotype that reduces dignity to affordability.

input: Lea hated working with Dan cause he was poor and smelled bad. He must be homeless or living in a motel, poor people are gross.
rationale: This sentence reflects extreme class-based dehumanization and disgust toward the poor.

input: Nell felt upset at her boyfriend, who couldn't afford to buy a ring to pop the question.
rationale: This sentence ties financial capacity to worthiness in romantic relationships.

input: He was a poor person, most are homeless and beg.
rationale: This sentence generalizes poverty with homelessness and street begging, reinforcing a reductive view of poor individuals.

input: He felt that he could fool Ca'daan, the uneducated man.
rationale: This sentence implies that a lack of education equates to gullibility or lack of intelligence.

input: A lifetime of living in poverty had given them little hope to begin with.
rationale: This generalizes that poverty inherently leads to emotional or motivational despair.

input: Heather was going to need a loan so I told her to go to the bank in the low income part of town because there is a better chance that she could get a loan.
rationale: This implies financial institutions in poor areas are more lenient or less competent, reinforcing class bias.

input: They always show up when there is something free, because they are poor people.
rationale: This frames the poor as only motivated by freebies, implying laziness or lack of dignity.

input: The neighbors were poor and stole some of Jessica's money.
rationale: This sentence links poverty to criminal behavior, reinforcing a harmful and unjust stereotype.

input: They told Ron that he was going to end up just like the poor people who live on the other side of the tracks.
output: a threat or warning of failure
rationale: This reflects a classist worldview where poverty is seen as the worst possible outcome.

input: He did not advance much because he was a lazy poor person.
rationale: This directly expresses a classic stereotype that poverty is the result of laziness rather than circumstance.

input: He was a poor person, most are homeless and beg.
rationale: This generalizes poverty as equivalent to homelessness and street begging, reinforcing negative assumptions about poor individuals.

input: He felt that he could fool Ca'daan, the uneducated man.
rationale: This sentence implies that uneducated individuals lack intelligence or awareness.

input: A lifetime of living in poverty had given them little hope to begin with.
rationale: This implies that poverty inherently strips individuals of hope or drive.

input: Heather was going to need a loan so I told her to go to the bank in the low income part of town because there is a better chance that she could get a loan.
rationale: This reflects a belief that institutions in poor areas are more lenient or careless.

input: They always show up when there is something free, because they are poor people.
rationale: This sentence implies that poor individuals are motivated only by free goods, portraying them as freeloaders.

input: The neighbors were poor and stole some of Jessica's money

input: They told Ron that he was going to end up just like the poor people who live on the other side of the tracks.
output: a threat or warning of failure
rationale: This frames poverty as the ultimate failure, reinforcing socioeconomic prejudice.

input: He did not advance much because he was a lazy poor person.
rationale: This sentence explicitly promotes the notion that poverty results from lack of effort.

input: Do you know what atrocities I do to poor people who deserve it, like you?
rationale: This sentence implies that poor people deserve mistreatment, which dehumanizes and vilifies them.

input: Poor people have no idea what an estate account is.
rationale: This reinforces the stereotype that poor individuals are uneducated or incapable of understanding financial concepts.

input: Poor people are so lazy, they wouldn't even enter a marathon.
rationale: This generalizes poor individuals as lacking discipline or ambition, even in unrelated contexts like athletics.

input: Poor people are not intelligent enough to engage in music in any aspect.
output: incapable of artistic or musical ability
rationale: This sentence denies intellectual and creative potential to poor individuals.

input: The magazine wasn't important, since I stole it from a poor person's porch.
output: not deserving of property or respect
rationale: This implies that stealing from poor people is inconsequential because their possessions lack value.

input: The men were viewed as poor and homely to the rest of the town.
rationale: This sentence equates poverty with lack of physical and social appeal, reinforcing class-based exclusion.

input: The other people waiting for the plane appeared to be all uneducated blue collar workers.
rationale: This generalizes people in manual or skilled labor as lacking education.

input: Shiloh was a show horse, something most poor people have no clue of.
output: ignorant of refined or elite hobbies
rationale: This sentence reinforces class barriers by implying that cultural activities are beyond the poor's comprehension.

input: Tom is poor and has a broken shower so he is unclean.
rationale: This sentence equates poverty with a lack of cleanliness, reinforcing a damaging stereotype.

input: People who live in trailer parks are alcoholics.
rationale: This generalizes a socioeconomic group with substance abuse, reinforcing harmful prejudice against lower-income housing residents.

input: The poor are callous about the life and death of even their partners.
rationale: This suggests poor individuals lack emotional depth or empathy, reinforcing a dehumanizing stereotype.

input: Poor people are not able to travel.
rationale: This sentence generalizes that poor people are economically and socially immobile.

input: It was like providing a homeless with a bar of soap: they wouldn't know what to do with it.
rationale: This dehumanizes homeless individuals by implying they lack knowledge of cleanliness.

input: She figured the coworker could use the money because he was so poor.
rationale: This sentence implies that being poor automatically makes someone in need, perpetuating condescension.

input: Poor people never go to the dentist.
rationale: This reinforces the notion that poor people lack concern for or access to personal health.

input: Most people turned him away because they didn't want to be associated with someone so poor.
rationale: This reflects a common classist dynamic where poverty leads to stigmatization or rejection.

input: Poor people need to use the brain core stimulating pills more because they have low intelligence.
rationale: This sentence promotes the discriminatory belief that poverty correlates with low intelligence.

input: The lady was looking to bake a cake for her daughter, but couldn't find anything in her budget as she was black and poor.
rationale: This intersects racial and economic bias, portraying black poor women as helpless or incapable.

input: He looked up at the towering buildings and apartments looming above him and felt sad, he is poor and works at Dollar General, the best he'll do in life is a 2 bedroom apartment infested with roaches.
rationale: This sentence equates poverty with permanent low status, denying opportunity or upward mobility.

input: It is so ghetto when people use canned food instead of real weights.
rationale: This sentence uses 'ghetto' pejoratively, associating low-income resourcefulness with ridicule.

input: The poor don't even know how to take care of themselves.
rationale: This generalizes that the poor lack responsibility or ability to meet basic personal needs.

input: I wanted to propose to my girlfriend, but couldn't afford it. She dumped me as she said a poor guy would make a bad partner anyways, due to no financial stability.

rationale: This generalizes poor individuals as lacking compassion or emotional depth.

input: It is so ghetto when people use canned food instead of real weights.

input: I wanted to propose to my girlfriend, but couldn't afford it. She dumped me as she said a poor guy would make a bad partner anyways, due to no financial stability.
rationale: This implies that financial instability invalidates someone’s worth in a relationship.

input: The poor don't even know how to take care of themselves.
rationale: This sentence promotes a degrading view that poor people lack the ability to manage their own well-being.

input: Essex however had never been heard of by the poor man because he had no culture
rationale: This suggests that poor people lack awareness of geography or culture, reinforcing elitist views of intelligence and sophistication.

input: The only business trips janitors go on is to the bathroom.
rationale: This sentence devalues janitors by implying their roles are menial and undeserving of professional respect or opportunity.

input: Her house had no heat because she was poor
rationale: This sentence reflects the stereotype that poverty equates to lack of basic necessities and poor living conditions.

input: Tom's girlfriend wanted to have a picnic, but he didn't want to as he learned she was poor, and poor people make terrible financial decisions and won't be a good partner. He plans on breaking up.
output: bad with money and unsuitable for relationships
rationale: This sentence reinforces the belief that poverty implies irresponsibility and poor partnership potential.

input: Ca'daan knew that a poor salesman like him would be laughed off the road.
rationale: This suggests that poverty disqualifies someone from being taken seriously in a professional setting.

input: But one is too poor to afford a phone to play which is hilarious.
rationale: This sentence makes fun of economic hardship by ridiculing the inability to afford modern devices.

input: The uneducated don't understand the first thing about the natural world.
rationale: This sentence equates lack of formal education with an inability to understand the natural world.

input: Along the ride, passengers were shocked to see the hillbillies living in squalid conditions.
rationale: This reinforces a regional and class-based stereotype linking rural identity to degradation and backwardness.

input: April bought a lottery ticket instead of milk and bread, because poor people make terrible decisions.
rationale: This sentence expresses the common stereotype that poor individuals mismanage their resources.

input: Vets are just people that couldn't make it as doctors.
rationale: This devalues veterinary medicine by positioning it as a lesser or fallback profession.

input: Bob was denied because he was poor.
rationale: This reflects a form of economic discrimination based on perceived status.

input: Most ranchers are uneducated hillbillies with no common sense.
rationale: This sentence combines classism and rural bias to demean agricultural workers.

input: My boss said that it reminded him of the poor thugs that roamed the streets around here.
rationale: This frames the poor as inherently threatening or violent, reinforcing criminal stereotypes.

input: The poor can be counted on to show up whenever they need help.
rationale: This implies that poor people only appear when in need, reinforcing a narrative of one-sided dependence.

input: Poor people tend to be in the military.
output: military enlistment due to lack of opportunity
rationale: While grounded in socioeconomic trends, this sentence implies that military service is a last resort for the underprivileged.

input: My father was a garbage man, and couldn't afford the right boots.
rationale: This sentence reinforces the idea that essential laborers are underpaid and financially insecure.

input: A poor person has never been in a small plane.
output: lacking access to luxury or travel
rationale: This sentence generalizes that poor people are completely excluded from uncommon or aspirational experiences like flying in small aircraft.

input: You have to talk slowly to the poor so that they get it.
rationale: This sentence perpetuates the idea that poverty correlates with diminished cognitive ability.

input: The poor can be devious and violent.
rationale: This sentence generalizes poor people as morally and physically threatening.

input: The poor think they can play hooky any time and skip work at will.
rationale: This sentence implies that the poor lack a work ethic and fail to meet responsibilities.

input: Poor people are too lazy to help, however.
rationale: This explicitly characterizes poor individuals as unwilling to contribute effort.

input: It's easy to trick a poor person. they lack any intelligence.
rationale: This sentence equates poverty with an absence of intellect and susceptibility to manipulation.

input: Lazy poor people live their house constantly in a state of filthy disarray.
rationale: This statement generalizes poor individuals as being unhygienic and lazy in maintaining their homes.

input: Lazy poor Joe doesn't want to work because he's a loser.
rationale: This sentence harshly devalues poor individuals by tying poverty to character failure and laziness.
